qas.question: When did the North American natives begin farming?
What had pottery become 4,000 years ago in the Americas?
What did technology make feasible when it came to trees?
How did Archaic Indians use fire?
What was the intentional burning of vegetation intended to mimic?

context: Natives of North America began practicing farming <a0_0>approximately 4,000 years ago<a0_0/>, late in the Archaic period of North American cultures. Technology had advanced to the point that pottery was becoming <a1_0>common<a1_0/> and the <a2_0>small-scale felling<a2_0/> of trees had become feasible. Concurrently, the Archaic Indians began using fire in <a3_0>a controlled manner<a3_0/>. Intentional burning of vegetation was used to mimic the <a4_0>effects of natural fires<a4_0/> that tended to clear forest understories. It made travel easier and facilitated the growth of herbs and berry-producing plants, which were important for both food and medicines.
